newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft Network to add virtual reality service.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft Network to add virtual reality service.

text.p: ParaGraph International Inc., a Silicon Valley company founded by Russian engineers, will develop a virtual-reality world for Microsoft Corp.'s online Microsoft Network, the two companies said Tuesday.

Under the arrangement ParaGraph, based in Campbell, Calif., will supply content for the project, code-named "Magic Resort," and will license its technology for three-dimensional environments to the software giant.
ParaGraph officials said the project will allow users to create "avatars," or animated versions of themselves, that can visit online versions of world cities, beginning with Moscow and Paris.

"This project is a stage in our strategy to create a virtual time machine, in which anybody can visit any city of the world, while at the same time experimenting with his or her identity and behaviour," said Stepan Pachikov, chairman and chief executive officer of ParaGraph.

Officials did not say when the service would be available on the Microsoft Network, but a similar project will go live within the next several weeks on People World, Japan's No. 2 online service, a company spokesman said.
Paragraph, which is privately held, was founded in 1989 by Pachikov, world chess champion Garry Kasparov and several engineers from the Russian Academy of Sciences.
It currently employs about 150 people, most of whom are based in the company's Moscow development centre.

In addition to its virtual reality technology, ParaGraph makes handwriting recognition software including a forthcoming version for hand-held computers that use Microsoft's Windows CE operating system.
Company officials predict that revenues will double to $14 million this year from $7 million in 1996.
